text: what's up guys welcome to life of bliss
today I'm going to be showing you how to
make a dartboard backer as well as how
to hang and back lies your own logo but
first if you're into home theater and
DIY projects like this be sure to
subscribe and hit that Bell notification
button to be notified when new videos
come out now let's get up to the garage
and get started first we'll start off
with the material I use for the backer
this is some 1 foot by 4 foot but joined
oak boards that I used I got these from
Menards they were actually on clearance
for $10 apiece so the price is right
plus I really like how there's much
different board lengths and colors on
here so once it's all stained up it
should look pretty good so the first
step is going to be to drill some Craig
holes in the back of these and join all
of them together to give me a 5 foot
tall by 4 foot wide single piece of oak
the Craig pocket hole jig is a great way
to easily attach boards together
especially for a project like this where
the back of the boards won't be seen if
you're interested in any of the tools
and parts I use for this project I'll
have links down in the description below
after adding glue to each side and
clamping them to a flat surface I attach
the boards together alternating the
direction of the screws it's important
to clamp each board down to get the
smoothest seem possible to reduce the
amount of sanding in the next step
I went over the whole board with an
orbital sander and 80 grit paper to
smooth out the seams then follow it up
with 220 grit paper
to hang the board on the wall I decided
to go with a French cleat system
I took some 3/4 inch plywood and cut it
at a 45 degree angle since this piece
would be directly against the wall I
used a countersink bit to recess the
screw heads and attach it to the board
the piece here on the right will attach
to the wall allowing the top piece
attached to the board to slide down and
lock into place since this will be
supporting quite a bit of weight I used
four inch screws to attach the board to
the wall when attaching both parts of
the cleat you'll want to make sure that
they are as level as possible as this
will determine how level the backer
board will be
the next thing to do was test it hanging
on the wall and see how level it was
while it was up on the wall I decided to
go ahead and mount the windmill blade
five dart board to get it centered so I
could lay out the other pieces on the
backer later mounting consists of a
Center bracket and three rotor lock
screws to secure it to the backer
once hanging off the center mount just
unscrew the rotor locks until the board
is tight against the backer
at this point I was questioning whether
or not I even needed a backer
with the dartboard centered I can now
start laying out the other pieces to the
backer first was the dart and marker
tray for this I used a 3-inch wide piece
of oak to create a groove in the center
of the board for the markers I used a
half inch groove bit on my router table
I didn't have a plunge router at the
time so I made do with the tools that I
had
[Music]
for holding the darts I found the center
of the board and made a mark every one
and a quarter inches to drill the holes
I use a drill press to get a consistent
angle and depth
I set the baseplate to a thirty degree
angle and drill the holes just slightly
bigger than the dart tips I went back to
the backer and drilled five pilot holes
to mount the tray to drill pilot holes
in the tray itself I flipped the backer
over and drilled the screws and just far
enough to where the tip was sticking out
of the other side this allowed me to
line up the tray and make indent marks
where the pilot hole should be
[Music]
I used the drill press to make sure that
the pilot holes were straight to mount
the tray I lined up the screw tips with
the pilot holes clamp down the tray with
a longer piece of wood and screwed it
into place next were the blackboards for
either side of the dart board
I took some measurements and made some
frames out of half-inch oak I didn't do
any fancy joinery for the frames I ended
up just gluing the ends clamping them to
a flat surface and driving a brad nail
and to hold while the glue dried I then
took a half inch rabbeting bit and made
a recessed area for the blackboard to
set in they ended up being just slightly
too big but I was able to cut them down
to size on the miter saw
[Music]
to attach them to the backer I used a
keyhole router bit to put two mounting
holes in the backside this will make
them easily removable in case I ever
need to change out the blackboard using
some tape for reference lines I was able
to lower the frames on to the bit and
move it down about a quarter-inch to
make the keyhole opening all that was
left to do for the frames was to Center
them and drill in some mounting screws
so the next step is to get this victory
sign attached to the backboard to do
that I've got some half-inch plywood
that I will be making a French pleat out
of to attach a sign as well some spacers
so I can run and attach the LED lights I
took a small piece of the half-inch
plywood and cut it at a 45 degree angle
for the French cleat after centering the
victory sign on the board I marked where
the cleat system would go the other
small piece will attach to the back of
the sign and slide into place before
attaching anything to the back of the
acrylic sign I cleaned it off with some
rubbing alcohol to remove any oils to
adhere the plywood I use some 100%
silicone caulk for running the lights
around the outside I attached a few more
pieces of plywood and let the silicone
set up for 24 hours before attaching the
lights I cut my strip to length and
attach to the plywood with some hot glue
I used a quick disconnect attachment
that I soldered an extension cable to
that will run to the LEDs controller and
power strip to see more on how the LEDs
are connected and setup be sure to check
out my how to video on wiring my entire
bar with LED lights
[Music]
for the stain I wanted to try and find
something that matched my bar area
fairly close I couldn't find a match
with a single stain but the dark walnut
gave me the color I was looking for and
then going over it with the classic gray
really got it close to the bar cabinets
here you can see a scrap piece of trim
from the bar area and the similar color
of the backer board for a top coat I
used a satin polyurethane clear coat
with a little bit of sanding between
coats two and three
after everything had dried for a few
days I drilled a hole for the LED wire
to go through and attach the black
boards to the frames to do this I just
secured them into place with some
silicone after hanging the board back on
the wall I routed the LED cable through
the wall to my back room where the
controller and power source was located
I also picked up a VIPRE laser throw
line marker since I didn't have a good
way to mark that off on carpet a quick
note while connecting and hanging the
victory sign you can use this method for
almost any sign that you may have the
silicon will stick to almost any
material and hold to the French cleat
I wouldn't recommend doing this with the
harley-davidson sign though as it may
leak oil onto your carpet and here is
how it all turned out
[Music]
so we are really happy with the way the
dartboard turned out this obviously
gives us something else to do down here
but also matches the bar area really
well and fills up the open space on this
wall like I said earlier the same
concept can be used with different types
and sizes of wood I just happen to
stumble upon this oak board at my local
Menards I will be leaving links to all
the products I use in the description
below if this video helped you out hit
that like button and be sure to
subscribe to see more DIY projects
thanks for watching and I will see you
guys soon alright cotton bullseye
bullseye again
I think I may need some more practice
you
